cheatsheetvideos.quote: Alexa shares with us how she went in for her Class A permit and decided to get her Hazmat endorsement as a bonus!
Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: Blocking cargo:
questions.answerB: Should be done to prevent the shifting of cargo.
questions.answerC: Can only be done with metal pieces.
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are techniques to keep cargo from shifting in transit. A piece of cargo should be blocked to its front, back, and/or sides to prevent movement.

questions.question: If you are driving at a reduced speed in a construction zone when you spot a construction worker near the road, you should:
questions.explanation: Always decrease your speed when traveling through a construction area. Slow down even further if there are workers on or near the roadway.

questions.question: If you see taillights ahead while you are driving in fog:
questions.answerA: The lights may not indicate where the road is as the vehicle may have pulled off the roadway.
questions.answerB: You can assume the vehicle ahead is on the road.
questions.answerC: It may be an optical illusion.
questions.explanation: When driving under foggy conditions, lights cannot be taken as a reliable indication of where the road is. The lights may be coming from a vehicle that has pulled off the road.

questions.question: To make your vehicle more visible during the day, you should:
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights should be used for best visibility, even during the day. Using high beam headlights around other drivers can be dangerous.

questions.question: When backing a truck, you should:
questions.answerA: Only use the side mirrors on the driver’s side.
questions.explanation: Backing a commercial motor vehicle is always dangerous because you cannot see everything behind you. When backing, make frequent checks of the mirrors on both sides of the vehicle. Use a helper whenever possible.

questions.question: When applying for a hazardous materials endorsement, being found guilty of which of the following is a disqualifying offense?
questions.explanation: Amongst other crimes, a felony conviction for arson will disqualify a person from obtaining, renewing, or transferring a hazardous materials endorsement.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should:
questions.answerA: Always pump the brakes several times before holding down the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Press down the brake pedal as hard as possible every time you slow or stop.
questions.explanation: Drivers of vehicles equipped with ABS and drivers of vehicles without ABS should brake in relatively the same manner. When ABS is working properly, it automatically applies when brakes are applied in situations that may create lockup.

questions.question: To ensure that you do not slow down traffic when driving a large truck, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to pass another vehicle while driving uphill.
questions.answerC: Stay in the right lane whenever possible.
questions.explanation: If a heavy load prevents your vehicle from keeping up with the speed of other traffic, you should stay in the right lane.

questions.question: ABS allows you to:
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to help prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. With ABS equipped on your vehicle, you should drive and brake in the same manner that you would without it.

questions.question: Hydroplaning:
questions.answerB: Usually happens when vehicles are traveling at speeds above 65 mph.
questions.answerC: Can occur with a minimal amount of water on the roadway.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be a large amount of water on the road for this to occur. Hydroplaning can begin at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: During the driving test, when encountering a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle on the tracks if the other vehicle is going too slow.
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle to check for a train.
questions.answerC: Not change gears while your vehicle is on the tracks.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, do not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in a railroad crossing.

questions.question: If unable to tell if the road is becoming icy and slippery, a driver:
questions.answerB: May open their window and feel the front of the side mirror for ice.
questions.answerC: Should look at the road closely.
questions.explanation: If you think the road surface may be becoming icy but you are not certain, you can open your window and feel the front of the side mirror, mirror support, or antenna. If ice has formed on any of these items, the road is likely becoming icy as well.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.explanation: Always speed up smoothly and gradually so that your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: If a load is 10 feet long, it must be secured by a minimum of ____ tie-downs.
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down. There should be at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Regardless of the size of the cargo, at least two tie-downs must be used.

questions.question: When driving in winter, which of the following should receive extra attention in a pre-trip inspection?
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-trip inspection during the winter, you should pay extra attention to the coolant level and amount of antifreeze; the defrosting and heating equipment; the wiper blades and windshield washer; the tires and tire chains; the lights and reflectors; the windows and mirrors; the hand holds, steps, and deck plates; the radiator shuttles and winterfront; and exhaust system.

questions.question: Alcohol can be removed from your system:
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate, so the only way to sober up after consuming alcohol is to allow your body time to remove the alcohol on its own.

questions.question: Parked delivery trucks may be hazardous because:
questions.answerB: People are often in a hurry when exiting such trucks and may not look for other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Packages often fall out of the trucks and into the road.
questions.explanation: Passing parked delivery or postal trucks can be dangerous because the driver may be in a hurry and pull into traffic without warning, or may they suddenly step out of the vehicle without checking for other traffic.

questions.question: Applicants seeking a hazardous materials endorsement must pass a threat assessment through which agency?
questions.explanation: Applicants seeking a hazardous materials endorsement must undergo a threat assessment conducted by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: When it’s difficult to see, such as at dawn or dusk, a driver can increase their vehicle's visibility by:
questions.explanation: When driving at dawn, at dusk, or in inclement weather, you should use your headlights on their low beam setting to increase your visibility.

questions.question: If there is a fire in your vehicle and you are not sure how to extinguish it, you should:
questions.answerB: Try douse the flames with water.
questions.answerC: Move away from the flames and wait for the firefighters.
questions.explanation: If you are not sure which method to use when putting out a fire, do not attempt to extinguish the fire on your own. Instead, wait for firefighters to arrive and let them handle it. This is especially true if you are experiencing a hazardous materials fire.

questions.question: When drivers turn, they usually:
questions.answerA: Look in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Look in the direction opposite the turn.
questions.explanation: When turning, drivers usually look in the direction of their turn. If a driver fails to signal before a turn or lane change, their body movements may still provide a clue that they are planning to turn.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult to see behind the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Most trucks do not have the ability to move in reverse.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.explanation: Backing a truck is always dangerous because the driver may not be able to see everything behind them. CMV operators should avoid backing whenever possible.

questions.question: After a vehicle is started, warning lights and buzzers:
questions.answerA: Should stay on for several minutes.
questions.answerB: Should turn off within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Should stay on until manually turned off.
questions.explanation: After a vehicle is started, the warning lights and buzzers should go out after a few seconds. If the warning signals do not turn off, there may be something wrong with the vehicle.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections should be done:
questions.answerA: Differently each time in order to place emphasis on different items.
questions.answerB: The same way each time to prevent you from forgetting anything.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip inspection should be completed in the same way before every drive. Consistency will help you learn all of the proper steps and decrease the likelihood that you will forget to check something.

questions.question: After an accident, flares should be used with caution because:
questions.answerA: There may be fuel spilled on the ground that could catch fire.
questions.answerB: Other drivers may not see the flares if the weather is sunny.
questions.explanation: A common cause of vehicle fires in the aftermath of an accident is the improper use of flares near spilled fuel. Use flares with caution.

questions.question: Your CDL will be revoked if:
questions.answerA: You want to add an endorsement.
questions.answerB: Your privilege to operate your personal vehicle is revoked.
questions.answerC: You have not paid a toll.
questions.explanation: If your privilege to operate your personal vehicle is revoked, canceled, or suspended due to moving traffic violations, you will also lose your CDL. This does not apply if your license is revoked due to parking violations.

questions.question: When operating a truck requiring a CDL:
questions.answerA: You are never required to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerB: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if transporting more than 500 pounds of cargo.
questions.answerC: You must always wear a seat belt.
questions.answerD: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if you are driving a tank vehicle.
questions.explanation: A driver's seat should always be equipped with a seat belt. You must wear a seat belt at all times while operating a CMV.

questions.question: Which gas would cause concern due to a faulty exhaust system?
questions.explanation: A leaking exhaust system can introduce carbon monoxide, which is poisonous, into the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal:
questions.answerA: Is not recommended on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Is required on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerC: Is optional on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.explanation: Any vehicle with air brakes must be equipped with a low air pressure warning signal.

questions.question: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check for all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Too much air pressure in your tires.
questions.answerB: Too little air pressure in your tires.
questions.answerC: A consistent name brand across all of your tires.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should verify that the air pressure is neither too low nor too high in any of your tires.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet instead of icy. Always be on the lookout for black ice if a road surface looks wet and temperatures are around the freezing mark.

questions.question: Within 10 minutes of stopping on the side of the road, you must:
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, you must place the appropriate emergency warning devices within 10 minutes of stopping.

questions.question: Black ice is:
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. The surface will look like a wet road. Always be alert to black ice if the road looks wet when the temperature is below freezing.

questions.question: An alcohol evaporator is especially important:
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems contain an alcohol evaporator. This evaporator introduces alcohol into the system to help prevent ice from forming in cold weather.

questions.question: A person driving with an open window in cold weather may be:
questions.answerB: A person who is dressed inappropriately.
questions.answerC: A person who likes fresh air.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they have their windows rolled down in cold weather.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to cover cargo?
questions.answerB: Protecting the cargo from the weather
questions.answerC: Preventing other drivers from looking at what is being transported
questions.explanation: The two basic reasons to cover cargo are to protect people from the cargo if it spills and to protect the cargo from weather conditions.

questions.question: To avoid a collision with a hazard on the roadway:
questions.answerA: You should always try to stop.
questions.answerB: Swerving may be a safer option than stopping.
questions.explanation: Swerving out of the way of a hazard is sometimes safer than trying to stop before reaching the hazard. You can usually turn away from something more quickly than you can come to a complete stop.

questions.question: How does doubling your speed from 20 mph to 40 mph affect your vehicle's braking distance?
questions.explanation: Increasing your vehicle's speed will increase your vehicle's striking power and braking distance. Doubling your vehicle's speed from 20 to 40 mph will quadruple its braking distance.

questions.question: The leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle with air brakes should be no more than ____ in one minute during a static leakage test.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a triple combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 5 psi in one minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection:
questions.answerA: Should be done in the same way every time.
questions.answerB: Should be done differently every time.
questions.answerC: Does not always need to include all items of concern.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip vehicle inspection should be done in the same way every time. Consistency will help a driver learn all of the proper steps and decrease the possibility of the driver forgetting to inspect something.

questions.question: A low air pressure warning signal:
questions.answerA: Is not required on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Is required on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.answerC: Is optional on vehicles with air brakes.
questions.explanation: A vehicle with air brakes must be equipped with a low air pressure warning signal. If the warning signal goes off while a vehicle is being driven, the driver should bring the vehicle to a complete stop and have the system repaired.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep downgrade:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be used.
questions.answerB: The vehicle should be placed in a low gear and the driver should use engine braking.
questions.answerC: The driver should continually downshift instead of using the brakes.
questions.explanation: On long and/or steep downgrades, you should primarily use engine braking to control the speed of your vehicle. Use your brakes only as a supplement to this effect.

questions.question: When driving, being aware of what is happening behind you is:
questions.explanation: When driving, it is important to be aware of what is happening behind and to the sides of your vehicle. Mirror checks and head checks should be a normal part of your scanning routine.

questions.question: What does the air compressor governor do?
questions.answerA: It stops the compressor from pumping air.
questions.answerB: It turns on the air compressor.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the storage tanks. It stops pumping if the pressure in the tanks becomes too high, and begins pumping if the pressure becomes too low.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.explanation: It is important to inspect your tires before every drive. Rust around wheel nuts may indicate that they are loose.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts can indicate that the nuts are loose. If you find rust near the wheel nuts, check their tightness before beginning to drive.

questions.question: To warn drivers behind you that you will be slowing down, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn on the right turn signal followed by the left turn signal.
questions.answerB: Tap your brake pedal a few times to illuminate your brake lights.
questions.answerC: Swerve from side to side to get their attention.
questions.explanation: To let drivers behind you know that you plan to slow down, lightly tap your brake pedal a few times to flash your brake lights. It is important to communicate your intentions to other drivers.

questions.question: If an unusual noise or feeling occurs in a vehicle while it is being driven, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume it is not a concern and continue driving.
questions.answerB: Hope the vehicle does alright until it is switched to another driver.
questions.answerC: Check the situation to determine the proper solution.
questions.explanation: If you see, hear, smell, or feel anything while driving that does not feel right, you should have it checked out.

questions.question: Mirrors should be:
questions.answerC: Checked only if there is a reason to suspect a problem.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should regularly check your mirrors, both to be aware of traffic and to check for problems on your own vehicle.

questions.question: A broken exhaust system can:
questions.answerA: Let poisonous fumes into the cab.
questions.explanation: Defects in an exhaust system are very dangerous because they can cause poisonous fumes to enter the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: When starting an engine:
questions.answerB: Warning lights should turn on, then quickly turn off.
questions.explanation: After a vehicle is started, the warning lights and buzzers should go out after a few seconds. If the warning signals do not turn off, there may be something wrong with the vehicle.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good rule when using turn signals?
questions.answerA: Signal early. Signal well before a turn or lane change.
questions.answerB: Signal continuously. Do not cancel a signal until the turn is completed.
questions.answerC: Don’t over-signal. If no one is near you, there is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: When using your turn signals, you should signal well before the turn or lane change, signal continuously throughout the turn or lane change, and cancel the signal after you have completed your move.

questions.question: Air brakes use ____ to function.
questions.explanation: Air brakes function through the use of compressed air.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should:
questions.answerA: Always pump the brakes several times before holding down the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Press down the brake pedal as hard as possible every time you slow or stop.
questions.explanation: Drivers of vehicles equipped with ABS and drivers of vehicles without ABS should brake in relatively the same manner. When ABS is working properly, it automatically applies when brakes are applied in situations that may create lockup.

questions.question: Brake linings should be:
questions.explanation: Brake linings should not be loose or soaked with oil or grease. They shouldn't be dangerously thin.

questions.question: Hydroplaning happens most often when:
questions.answerA: A vehicle is traveling faster than 60 mph.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is most likely to occur when driving on wet roads with tire pressure that is too low and tire tread that is too worn. If there is enough water on the road, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Place as little weight as possible over the axles.
questions.answerB: Place a well-balanced amount of weight over the axles.
questions.answerC: Place weight over only the axles.
questions.explanation: A load of cargo must be properly balanced. Placing too much weight over an axle can damage the axle and make it more difficult for you to steer. Placing too little weight over an axle can cause poor traction, also leading to difficult handling.

questions.question: When inspecting your tires, you do not want to find:
questions.answerA: Tire tread that is 4/32 of an inch deep.
questions.explanation: There should be at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on front tires and 2/32 of an inch on other tires. Valve stems should not be cut or cracked. Tire sizes should not be mismatched.

questions.question: A bridge formula:
questions.answerA: Permits less weight per axle for axles that are close together.
questions.answerC: Is not a concern for drivers.
questions.explanation: Maximum axle weights are often set by a bridge formula, which sets a lower maximum weight for axles that are close together.

questions.question: What is reaction distance?
questions.answerA: The distance you will travel between realizing you must brake and when you physically hit the brakes
questions.answerB: The distance you will travel between a hazard becoming visible and you seeing the hazard
questions.answerC: The distance you will travel between seeing a hazard and realizing you must brake
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's stopping distance can be calculated by adding together your perception distance, your reaction distance, and your vehicle's braking distance. Reaction distance is the distance traveled between the moment you mentally perceive a hazard and the moment you physically hit the brakes.

questions.question: The safety belt should:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should verify that the safety belt is securely mounted, adjusts, latches properly, and is not ripped or frayed.

questions.question: Once cargo is secured onto a vehicle:
questions.answerA: You do not need to inspect the cargo.
questions.answerB: You should not let others inspect the cargo.
questions.answerC: You should check the cargo every 150 miles.
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles thereafter.

questions.question: If you plan to transport hazardous materials, you must pass which endorsement test?
questions.explanation: You must have a hazardous materials endorsement to drive a vehicle of any size that is used to transport defined classes of hazardous materials.

questions.question: When driving in winter, which of the following should receive extra attention in a pre-trip inspection?
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-trip inspection during the winter, you should pay extra attention to the coolant level and amount of antifreeze; the defrosting and heating equipment; the wiper blades and windshield washer; the tires and tire chains; the lights and reflectors; the windows and mirrors; the hand holds, steps, and deck plates; the radiator shuttles and winterfront; and exhaust system.

questions.question: When operating a truck requiring a CDL:
questions.answerA: You are never required to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerB: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if transporting more than 500 pounds of cargo.
questions.answerC: You must always wear a seat belt.
questions.answerD: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if you are driving a tank vehicle.
questions.explanation: A driver's seat should always be equipped with a seat belt. You must wear a seat belt at all times while operating a CMV.

questions.question: Which of the following vehicles is not exempted in requiring the driver to hold a CDL?
questions.explanation: Subject to certain conditions, a CDL is not required to operate military vehicles, authorized emergency vehicles, farm equipment, or recreational vehicles. It is also not required for operating a straight truck that contains only your personal property that you are not selling.

questions.question: A poor balance of weight in a trailer:
questions.explanation: Poorly balanced weight in a trailer can make handling unsafe. For example, either too little or too much weight on the front axle can make a vehicle difficult to steer. Weight should be distributed evenly from front to back and from side to side. It should be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: Loading cargo improperly:
questions.explanation: Proper loading and securement of cargo is essential for safety. Improperly loaded cargo could damage a vehicle, as well as cause injury or death by falling off in a collision or sudden stop.

questions.question: When near a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: You should expect to hear every approaching train.
questions.answerB: You may not hear a train, even if one is approaching.
questions.answerC: You will hear two short blasts of a train's horn if a train is approaching.
questions.explanation: You should never assume that you will hear an approaching train. The train operator may fail to sound the horn, or the use of a train's horn may be prohibited in a specific area. Even if the train does sound its horn, noise from inside your own vehicle may prevent you from hearing the train until it is dangerously close.

questions.question: If you identify a distracted driver on the road, you should:
questions.explanation: If you encounter a driver who seems distracted on the road, you should give them plenty of room and maintain a safe following distance.

questions.question: When making tight maneuvers, it is important for a driver to:
questions.answerA: Open their door for a better look.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should always be part of your driving routine, you should make a particular point of checking the mirrors when changing lanes, turning, merging, or making tight maneuvers.

questions.question: Your horn should be used to:
questions.answerA: Tell other drivers that you are angry.
questions.answerB: Warn other drivers that you are near.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's horn is a tool to warn others of your presence. Because the horn may create danger by startling other drivers, you should use it only if necessary.

questions.question: Aggressive driving is:
questions.answerA: Operating a vehicle in a selfish or pushy manner.
questions.answerB: Operating a vehicle with a strong regard for other motorists’ safety.
questions.answerC: Operating a vehicle in the left lane.
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is the act of operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner and without regard for the rights or safety of other road users.

questions.question: If involved in an accident, which of the following is not recommended?
questions.answerA: Trying to move your vehicle to the side of the road
questions.explanation: When involved in an accident, you should protect the area, notify authorities, care for the injured, collect required information, and report the accident. You can lose your license for leaving the scene of an accident.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet instead of icy. Always be on the lookout for black ice if a road surface looks wet and temperatures are around the freezing mark.

questions.question: If other vehicles are having a difficult time getting around your truck on a road with two or more lanes, you should:
questions.explanation: You should stay in the right lane of a multilane road if your vehicle is being slowed down by a heavy load. Allow other vehicles to pass your truck using the left lane.

questions.question: Texting while driving is especially dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is both a mental and physical distraction.
questions.answerB: A message may be upsetting to the driver.
questions.answerC: People like to read and may become too engaged in their phones.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is particularly dangerous because it is both a mental and physical distraction to the driver. In addition to diverting a driver's mental attention away from the road, texting requires a person to remove at least one hand from the vehicle's controls.

questions.question: If a load is 40 feet long, the minimum number of tie-downs required to secure the load is:
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down. There should be at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Regardless of the size of the cargo, at least two tie-downs must be used.

questions.question: If approaching a railroad crossing that is being approached by a train, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to cross the tracks quickly.
questions.answerC: Stop and wait for the train to pass before beginning across the tracks.
questions.explanation: Never attempt to beat a train to a railroad crossing. It is very difficult to accurately judge the speed of an approaching train. If you come upon a crossing that is being approached by a train, you must stop and wait for the train to pass before you attempt to cross the tracks.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated while driving a large vehicle, do all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: If you find yourself being tailgated by another driver, you should increase your following distance and avoid making quick moves. Increasing your speed may only result in the other driver continuing to tailgate you at a higher speed. Do not turn on your taillights or flash your brake lights at the other driver.

questions.question: Alcohol is removed from the body:
questions.answerC: More quickly if the person stays awake.
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate. Despite popular belief, tricks like drinking coffee or taking a cold shower will not speed up the process. The only way to become sober is to allow your body the time it needs to remove the alcohol from your system.

questions.question: On slippery roads, you should:
questions.answerB: Adjust your driving to match weather conditions.
questions.explanation: On a slippery road, you must adjust your driving speed to fit conditions. Because it will take longer for your vehicle to stop on a slippery road than on a dry road, you should increase your following distance when conditions are slippery. Avoid driving in a way that requires you to change speeds frequently.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerB: Are acceptable to be used on tires in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable to be used if carrying a light load.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims with welding repairs are never safe to use.

questions.question: Looking far ahead of your vehicle while driving is:
questions.answerA: Discouraged, as there is little you can do about something far up the road.
questions.answerB: Encouraged to help you identify hazards as early as possible.
questions.explanation: Good drivers look down the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. This makes it possible to identify hazards early, when drivers are more likely to have time to respond appropriately.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks:
questions.answerB: Take special care to be driven.
questions.answerC: Are usually not allowed to cross railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: Dry bulk tanks require special care to be driven, both because they have high centers of gravity and because the weight of the load can shift in transit.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, a CDL applicant may be asked to:
questions.explanation: When checking the engine compartment during the vehicle inspection test, you will need to check the engine oil level.

questions.question: Talking on a hands-free phone while driving:
questions.answerB: Only distracts the driver if the driver is speaking.
questions.answerC: Can be distracting to the driver.
questions.explanation: While speaking on a hands-free phone while driving is less dangerous than speaking on a hand-held phone, it is just as likely to mentally distract a driver. Simply engaging in conversation takes their mental focus away from the task of driving.

questions.question: What does the air compressor governor do?
questions.answerA: It stops the compressor from pumping air.
questions.answerB: It turns on the air compressor.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the storage tanks. It stops pumping if the pressure in the tanks becomes too high, and begins pumping if the pressure becomes too low.

questions.question: In a leaf spring:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's suspension, verify that leaf springs do not have missing or broken leaves. If at least one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing, the vehicle will be put out-of-service until the defect is fixed.

questions.question: Blocking a load:
questions.answerA: Is dangerous and should never be done.
questions.answerC: Is only done with liquid cargo.
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are used to prevent cargo from shifting in transit.

questions.question: If you will be transporting hazardous materials that require placards, you must:
questions.answerA: Ask permission of the local law enforcement agency.
questions.explanation: You must have a hazardous materials endorsement to transport a material that requires placards.

questions.question: Blocking cargo:
questions.answerB: Should be done to prevent shifting of cargo.
questions.answerC: Should only be done with welded material.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be blocked to prevent it from sliding around in transit. The shifting of weight in transit can make steering and handling difficult for the driver.

questions.question: When transporting a load, you should inspect the cargo:
questions.answerB: At the end of each day.
questions.answerC: Every time you take a break.
questions.explanation: Cargo and its securement must be inspected every time you take a break during a trip. Be sure to inspect the cargo at least every 150 miles.

questions.question: If a worker is present in a work zone, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving at the posted speed limit.
questions.answerB: Slow to a speed under the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: When driving through a work zone, follow the posted speed limits. If workers are present, you should slow to a speed that is even lower than the posted limit.

questions.question: Cargo with a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Can make a vehicle likely to tip over.
questions.explanation: Cargo with a high center of gravity makes a vehicle more likely to tip over than cargo with a low center of gravity. For this reason, it is important that the weight of cargo be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the ____ come on automatically when air pressure falls below 45 psi.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when air tank pressure falls to a level between 20 and 45 psi. You can do this by chocking the wheels and releasing air from the braking system by stepping on and off the brake pedal. Once the pressure levels drop to an unsafe level, the parking brake valve should pop out and spring brakes should come on.

questions.question: Dual tires should:
questions.answerA: Not both be in contact with the road surface.
questions.answerC: Be different sizes from one another.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle, you should verify that your dual tires do not come into contact with one another, or with any other part of the vehicle.

questions.question: A broken exhaust system:
questions.answerA: Can allow poisonous fumes to enter the cabin.
questions.explanation: A broken exhaust system can let poisonous fumes into a vehicle's cab or sleeper berth. Be sure to inspect your exhaust system for any loose, broken, or missing parts.

questions.question: By beginning a left turn before reaching the center of an intersection, you:
questions.answerA: Will likely complete the turn satisfactorily.
questions.answerB: May hit other vehicles with the left side of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Can expect other drivers to move their vehicles to accommodate your turn.
questions.explanation: When planning to turn left at an intersection, make sure you have reached the center of the intersection before beginning the turn. If you turn too soon, off-tracking may cause the left side of your vehicle to hit another vehicle.

questions.question: Shortly after a tire has been changed, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop to make sure the lug nuts are still tight.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, you should stop a short while later to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: The tire load:
questions.answerA: Can be exceeded in cooler conditions.
questions.answerB: Is the maximum safe weight a tire can carry at a given pressure.
questions.answerC: Must be written in the shipping papers.
questions.explanation: Tire load is the maximum weight a tire can safely carry at a given pressure. This rating is stated on the side of each tire.

questions.question: When slowing down, you should ____ to warn other drivers
questions.explanation: Before slowing down, it can be a good idea to lightly tap your brakes. This will cause your brake lights to flash, providing a warning to motorists behind you.

questions.question: Which gas would cause concern due to a faulty exhaust system?
questions.explanation: A leaking exhaust system can introduce carbon monoxide, which is poisonous, into the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the other driver.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver doesn't see you.
questions.explanation: Whenever you pass another driver, bicyclist, or pedestrian, you should assume as a precaution that they do not see you.

questions.question: What is road rage?
questions.answerA: Operating a motor vehicle with the intent of doing harm to others
questions.answerB: Operating a motor vehicle that is deemed unsafe
questions.answerC: Operating a motor vehicle that has not been inspected
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is defined as operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner. Road rage is defined as operating a motor vehicle with the intent of doing harm to others, or the intent of physically assaulting another driver or their vehicle.

questions.question: How does doubling your speed from 20 mph to 40 mph affect your vehicle's braking distance?
questions.explanation: Increasing your vehicle's speed will increase your vehicle's striking power and braking distance. Doubling your vehicle's speed from 20 to 40 mph will quadruple its braking distance.

questions.question: Your CDL will be revoked if:
questions.answerA: You want to add an endorsement.
questions.answerB: Your privilege to operate your personal vehicle is revoked.
questions.answerC: You have not paid a toll.
questions.explanation: If your privilege to operate your personal vehicle is revoked, canceled, or suspended due to moving traffic violations, you will also lose your CDL. This does not apply if your license is revoked due to parking violations.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet instead of icy. Always be on the lookout for black ice if a road surface looks wet and temperatures are around the freezing mark.

questions.question: If a load is 40 feet long, it should be secured by at least ____ tie-downs.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be restrained by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. However, all cargo should have at least two tie-downs, no matter the size of the cargo.

questions.question: One way to prevent fatigue on long trips is to:
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming fatigued on a long trip, you should take a break after every 100 miles or two hours of driving. Driving through the night, or during any other time when you would normally be asleep, raises the danger of fatigue.

questions.question: When approaching a vehicle for a pre-trip inspection, a driver should look under the vehicle:
questions.answerA: To see if the vehicle is on an incline.
questions.answerB: To see if there are any fresh fluids on the ground.
questions.answerC: To see if the vehicle is in a parking spot.
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle before an inspection, make note of its general condition and ensure that it is not damaged or leaning. Look under the vehicle for fresh leaks of oil, grease, or fuel. Check around the vehicle for hazards to movement, such as people, other vehicles, or low-hanging wires or tree limbs.

questions.question: Oversized loads:
questions.answerA: Can never be transported by a truck.
questions.answerB: Should only be transported during the day.
questions.answerC: Should receive proper authorization to ensure compliance with state and local laws.
questions.explanation: Special permits are required for loads that are over-size, over-length, or overweight.

questions.question: By beginning a left turn before reaching the center of an intersection, you:
questions.answerA: Will likely complete the turn satisfactorily.
questions.answerB: May hit other vehicles with the left side of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Can expect other drivers to move their vehicles to accommodate your turn.
questions.explanation: When planning to turn left at an intersection, make sure you have reached the center of the intersection before beginning the turn. If you turn too soon, off-tracking may cause the left side of your vehicle to hit another vehicle.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should not let yourself be provoked by any angry gestures they make toward you. Avoid making eye contact with the other driver and do not try to race them.

questions.question: On any upgrade, gravity will:
questions.explanation: A vehicle will be slowed down by gravity on any uphill grade. You may need to switch to a lower gear to climb a steep grade.

questions.question: Items on a flatbed:
questions.answerA: Are usually heavy enough to not need to be strapped down.
questions.answerB: Should not be strapped down if you are driving more slowly than 35 mph.
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down to prevent it from shifting or falling off in transit.

questions.question: To ensure normal stopping power, drivers of vehicles equipped with a front brake limiting valve should:
questions.answerB: Set the control to the off position.
questions.answerC: Set the control to the neutral position.
questions.explanation: Some older vehicles have front brake limiting valves with "normal" and "slippery" settings. Setting a brake limiting valve to "slippery" reduces the vehicle's stopping power, so a driver should make sure the valve is in its "normal" position. Front wheel braking has proven to be effective in all driving conditions.

questions.question: If convicted of any traffic violations, excluding parking violations, you must:
questions.answerB: Place a sign on the back of your vehicle noting the conviction.
questions.answerC: Forfeit your CDL for six months.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any kind of traffic violation, in any type of vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days. You must also inform your motor vehicle licensing agency of the violation within 30 days if the conviction happened in another jurisdiction. This rule does not apply to parking infractions.

questions.question: When a vehicle is started, the coolant temperature should:
questions.explanation: After an engine is started, the coolant temperature should rise gradually to a normal operating range.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving skills test:
questions.answerA: You do not have to take the test with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.
questions.answerB: You must take the test with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.
questions.answerC: It does not matter which type of vehicle you use to take the test.
questions.explanation: CDL skills tests, including the on-road test, must be taken with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.

questions.question: If a vehicle is accompanied by a vehicle inspection report:
questions.answerA: The driver should first inspect the vehicle, then compare their notes with the report.
questions.answerB: The driver should first look at the report when completing an inspection.
questions.answerC: The driver should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and should rely only on the report.
questions.explanation: As the first step of a vehicle inspection, a driver should review any inspection report left by the previous driver.

questions.question: A stopped bus:
questions.answerA: Is not a cause for concern since it is stopped.
questions.answerB: Is only a concern if passengers are exiting the bus.
questions.answerC: Is a concern whether or not passengers are visible.
questions.explanation: You should always exercise caution when driving near a stopped bus. There could be passengers in the vicinity and the bus may either prevent them from seeing you or you from seeing them.

questions.question: The two indicators that determine when you should upshift are:
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: If you plan to slow down, you can warn drivers behind you by:
questions.answerB: Tapping the brakes a few times and before braking.
questions.answerC: Turning on one set of turn signals.
questions.explanation: Before slowing down, it is a good idea to flash your brake lights by lightly tapping your brake pedal a few times. This will warn drivers behind you of your plans to slow down.

questions.question: Aggressive driving is:
questions.answerA: Operating a vehicle in a selfish or pushy manner.
questions.answerB: Operating a vehicle with a strong regard for other motorists’ safety.
questions.answerC: Operating a vehicle in the left lane.
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is the act of operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner and without regard for the rights or safety of other road users.

questions.question: If you are driving in fog, you should not:
questions.explanation: If you must drive in fog, be sure to slow down. Turn on your flashers and low beam headlights.

questions.question: Talking on a hands-free phone while driving:
questions.answerB: Only distracts the driver if the driver is speaking.
questions.answerC: Can be distracting to the driver.
questions.explanation: While speaking on a hands-free phone while driving is less dangerous than speaking on a hand-held phone, it is just as likely to mentally distract a driver. Simply engaging in conversation takes their mental focus away from the task of driving.

questions.question: When inspecting the windshield before a trip, a person should do all the following, except:
questions.answerA: Remove and sharpen the wiper blades.
questions.answerB: Check the windshield wipers for proper spring tension.
questions.answerC: Check the wiper blades for damage.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your windshield, you should look for cracks or other problems that could interfere with your ability to clearly see the road. The windshield wiper arms should be checked for proper spring tension. The wiper blades should be checked for damage, stiff rubber, and improper securement.

questions.question: Steering wheel play should be no more than:
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should have no more than 10 degrees of play. This is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch wheel. If there is more play than this, it may be difficult to steer.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, belts should be:
questions.answerC: Inspected, but only about once a month.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check all belts for tightness and excessive wear.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, belts should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check all belts for tightness and excessive wear. You should learn how much "give" is appropriate for each belt.

questions.question: As the driver of a truck carrying a load, you are responsible for all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Knowing the phone numbers of all fire departments along your intended route of travel.
questions.explanation: It is the driver's responsibility to inspect their cargo; recognize overloading or poorly balanced weight; know that the cargo is properly secured and does not obscure the driver's view; and know that the cargo does not restrict access to emergency equipment. The driver is responsible for their cargo even if they were not the one who initially loaded and secured the cargo.

questions.question: What can happen if the air pressure gets too low in an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can let air out of the braking system faster than the compressor can replace it. Air brakes may cease to work effectively if the pressure becomes too low.

questions.question: Water that has collected on a roadway can cause:
questions.explanation: The risk of hydroplaning begins when water has collected on the surface of a road.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerA: Are not safe to be used.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable only when traveling at speeds under 40 mph.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are never safe for use.

questions.question: When should you slow for a curve?
questions.explanation: You should always slow to a safe speed before entering a curve. Slowing while within the curve could cause a skid.

questions.question: When driving, your mirrors should:
questions.answerA: Not be used, as they are distracting.
questions.answerB: Not be used unless there is traffic.
questions.explanation: It is important for you to be aware of your surroundings at all times. To do this, regularly check your mirrors.

questions.question: What is the minimum number of tie-downs required to secure a 10-foot piece of cargo?
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down. There should be at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Regardless of the size of the cargo, at least two tie-downs must be used.

questions.question: When making a left turn, you should start the turn:
questions.answerA: Before reaching the center of the intersection.
questions.answerB: No sooner than the center of the intersection.
questions.answerC: After your rear wheels have passed the center of the intersection.
questions.explanation: When making a left turn, you should wait until you reach the center of the intersection before actually beginning to turn. Due to off-tracking, the left side of your vehicle could hit another driver if you begin turning too early.

questions.question: One way to avoid becoming an aggressive driver is to:
questions.answerA: Talk on your cell phone while driving.
questions.answerC: Set realistic expectations regarding travel time.
questions.explanation: To help avoid frustration, which can lead to aggressive driving behavior, you should begin a trip with realistic expectations about your travel time. Plan ahead to allow time for potential traffic delays. Other strategies to help prevent aggressive driving behavior include driving an appropriate speed and keeping a reasonable following distance; avoiding making gestures at other drivers; and keeping your hands on the steering wheel.

questions.question: Emergency equipment, such as fire extinguishers, are:
questions.answerA: Only needed in vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Required in all commercial motor vehicles.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles must carry appropriate emergency equipment, including fire extinguishers.

questions.question: Maintaining a cushion of space between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead is:
questions.answerA: Not encouraged, as it slows the flow of traffic.
questions.answerB: Encouraged, as it allows you time to react to unexpected hazards.
questions.answerC: Only encouraged if you are traveling with a passenger.
questions.explanation: For safe driving, it is essential that you maintain cushions of space on all sides of your vehicle. This helps to ensure that you will have time to take appropriate action if a problem arises.

questions.question: You are especially likely to encounter strong winds when:
questions.explanation: Strong winds can make it difficult to keep a vehicle in its proper lane. Strong wind can be a particular problem when a vehicle is being driven out of a tunnel.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be applied.
questions.answerB: The parking brake should be applied.
questions.answerC: Brakes should not be applied if the vehicle is left out of gear.
questions.explanation: Parking brakes should be used whenever you park. If necessary, chock your wheels.

questions.question: When using a fire extinguisher on a fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Get as close to the fire as possible.
questions.answerB: Stand as far away from the fire as possible.
questions.answerC: Aim the extinguisher at the top of the fire.
questions.explanation: When using a fire extinguisher, you should stand as far away from the fire as possible. Aim the extinguisher at the base of the fire, not at the flames. If you are not sure which kind of extinguisher should be used on a fire, particularly a hazardous materials fire, you should wait for the firefighters to arrive and allow them to extinguish it.

questions.question: Compared to talking on a cell phone while driving, texting while driving is:
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is even more dangerous than speaking on a phone while driving. In addition to being mentally distracting, texting is also physically distracting.

questions.question: To avoid a collision with a hazard on the roadway:
questions.answerA: You should always try to stop.
questions.answerB: Swerving may be a safer option than stopping.
questions.explanation: Swerving out of the way of a hazard is sometimes safer than trying to stop before reaching the hazard. You can usually turn away from something more quickly than you can come to a complete stop.

questions.question: When driving, being aware of what is happening behind you is:
questions.explanation: When driving, it is important to be aware of what is happening behind and to the sides of your vehicle. Mirror checks and head checks should be a normal part of your scanning routine.

questions.question: Headache racks:
questions.answerB: Help protect the driver from the cargo.
questions.explanation: Front-end header boards, also known as "headache racks," protect the driver from cargo moving in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: When applying for a hazardous materials endorsement, being found guilty of which of the following is a disqualifying offense?
questions.explanation: Amongst other crimes, a felony conviction for arson will disqualify a person from obtaining, renewing, or transferring a hazardous materials endorsement.

questions.question: If you have more than one license:
questions.answerC: You may get caught through the states' shared computer network.
questions.explanation: All states share driver information through a computerized database in order to prevent the issuance of multiple licenses to a single person. It is prohibited for a person to have more than one driver license.

questions.question: Texting while driving is:
questions.answerA: Allowed if you are contacting your employer.
questions.answerB: Allowed when driving on rural roads.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is dangerous and is never permitted while operating a CMV.

questions.question: When in heavy traffic, the safest driving speed is:
questions.answerA: Slower than the speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.answerB: The same speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.answerC: Faster than the speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.explanation: In heavy traffic, it is safest to travel at the same speed as other vehicles. If two vehicles continue to drive in the same direction at the same speed, they cannot hit each other.

questions.question: If taking the driving test and the route does not include a railroad crossing, you:
questions.answerA: Will not have to do anything related to a crossing.
questions.answerB: May have to explain how you would cross railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Will have to take the test again on a route that does include a railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: If your on-road driving test route does not include a railroad crossing, you may be asked to explain and demonstrate the proper railroad crossing procedures to the examiner at a simulated location.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indicator of when to upshift?
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: When starting an engine, oil pressure should come up to a normal level:
questions.explanation: Look at your truck's gauges when starting the engine. The oil pressure in an engine should come up to a normal level within seconds of the vehicle's engine being started.

questions.question: If making a tight turn, the operator of a CMV should:
questions.answerA: Be able to drive as fast as the driver of a car.
questions.answerB: Not be concerned about speed, but focus on the road.
questions.answerC: Warn drivers behind by braking early and slowing gradually.
questions.explanation: Drivers behind you may not anticipate how slowly your CMV must travel to safely make a right turn. You can help warn them in advance by braking early and slowing gradually.

questions.question: Wheels with welding repairs are:
questions.answerA: Safe to be used if the repairs were done by a professional.
questions.answerB: Safe to be used if the repair seems solid.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use. They should be replaced before the vehicle is taken on the road.

questions.question: ____ are the most likely to be affected by strong winds.
questions.explanation: Strong winds can make it difficult for a driver to maintain control of their vehicle. Usually, this is especially true for drivers of lighter CMVs.

questions.question: The only way to sober up after consuming alcohol is to:
questions.explanation: Most alcohol is removed from the body by the liver, which processes alcohol at a fixed rate. Despite popular belief, techniques like drinking black coffee or taking a cold shower will not accelerate this process. The only thing you can do to become sober after drinking is allow your body the time it needs to eliminate the alcohol from your system.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving skills test:
questions.answerA: You do not have to take the test with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.
questions.answerB: You must take the test with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.
questions.answerC: It does not matter which type of vehicle you use to take the test.
questions.explanation: CDL skills tests, including the on-road test, must be taken with the type of vehicle for which you want to be licensed.

questions.question: Cargo inside a trailer:
questions.answerA: Does not need to be secured.
questions.answerB: Should be stacked no more than three feet high.
questions.answerC: Should be secured to prevent movement.
questions.explanation: Cargo inside a trailer must be secured appropriately to prevent it from shifting in transit.

questions.question: Vehicle inspections are required:
questions.explanation: Drivers are required under federal and state law to inspect their vehicles before every trip.

questions.question: ____ is an example of required emergency equipment.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: To determine if a vehicle can handle a load, you should:
questions.answerB: Know the tire rating for the front tires only.
questions.answerC: Start driving and see if the vehicle is handling well.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to make sure their vehicle is not overloaded. They must be aware of legal weight limits and the maximum weight that their vehicle is rated to carry, including the weight capacity rating of the suspension system.

questions.question: When backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Move quickly to get out of other drivers' ways.
questions.answerB: Try not to use the mirrors.
questions.explanation: Driving in reverse is always dangerous because you cannot see everything behind your vehicle. Whenever possible, use a helper to monitor your blind spots.

questions.question: Air tank drains should:
questions.answerA: Not be used by the driver.
questions.answerB: Only be used when it is wet outside.
questions.answerC: Be used to drain the tanks completely.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: When you must travel down a hill, when should you switch into a lower gear?
questions.answerA: As you begin to move downward
questions.answerB: As you go downhill and pick up speed
questions.explanation: You should always slow down and shift into a lower gear before starting down a hill. If you do not begin to drive down a hill at a low enough speed, you risk overusing your brakes, causing them to overheat and fade.

questions.question: What does a vehicle inspection report do?
questions.answerA: Tells the motor carrier about problems that may need fixing
questions.answerB: Ensures that the vehicle is inspected regularly
questions.answerC: Holds drivers accountable for inspecting the vehicle
questions.explanation: Drivers may be required to submit a written vehicle inspection report at the end of each day of driving. The motor carrier must repair any items in the report that affect safety and certify on the report that repairs were either made or unnecessary.

questions.question: To use the controlled braking method, you should:
questions.answerB: Apply your brakes as firmly as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.explanation: Controlled braking is the method of applying a vehicle's brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels. A driver should keep steering wheel movements very small if braking while using this method.

questions.question: Aggressive driving is:
questions.answerA: Operating a vehicle in a selfish or pushy manner.
questions.answerB: Operating a vehicle with a strong regard for other motorists’ safety.
questions.answerC: Operating a vehicle in the left lane.
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is the act of operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner and without regard for the rights or safety of other road users.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles thereafter.

questions.question: How can you check for a leak in hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brake pedal three times, then hold down the pedal for five seconds. If the pedal moves, there may be a problem.
questions.answerB: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and release. If the brake pedal returns to its normal position, there may be a problem.
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and release. If the brake squeaks, there may be a problem.
questions.explanation: Check hydraulic brakes by pumping the brake pedal three times before applying firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak or some other problem in the braking system.

questions.question: ____ make up the emergency brake system.
questions.answerA: Only parts of the parking brake system
questions.answerB: Only parts of the service brake system
questions.answerC: Parts of the parking and service brake systems
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, there are three different braking systems: a service brake system, a parking brake system, and an emergency brake system. The emergency brake system uses parts of both the parking and service brake systems.

questions.question: ABS brakes:
questions.answerC: Prevent your vehicle from accelerating when going uphill.
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up when the driver brakes hard on a slippery surface.

questions.question: When pulled over to the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Rely on your taillights to alert other motorists to your presence.
questions.answerC: Use your four-way emergency flashers to alert other motorists to your presence.
questions.explanation: When stopped on the side of the road, be sure to turn on your vehicle's four-way emergency flashers, especially during times of lowered visibility. Place warning devices within 10 minutes of being stopped.

questions.question: A broken exhaust system can:
questions.answerA: Let poisonous fumes into the cab.
questions.explanation: Defects in an exhaust system are very dangerous because they can cause poisonous fumes to enter the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should:
questions.explanation: If someone is following you too closely, you should open up the space in front of your vehicle to make it easier for the tailgater to pass. Speeding up is counterproductive because the other driver may just continue tailgating you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: If feeling drowsy while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and finish the trip.
questions.answerB: Drive faster to reach your destination more quickly.
questions.answerC: Safely leave the road and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel drowsy while driving, the best thing to do is to stop and get some sleep. A driver trying to push on and finish a trip while fatigued is a major cause of fatal accidents.

questions.question: Interstate carriers must have what information affixed to the commercial motor vehicles in their fleet?
questions.explanation: Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations (FMCSR) require carriers to affix the legal name or single trade name to each CMV in their fleet.

questions.question: Air storage tanks:
questions.answerA: Are not allowed on a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Hold compressed air for the brakes.
questions.answerC: Should be drained of excess air after every trip.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks hold compressed air to be used by the brakes. The number and size of air tanks varies among vehicles.

questions.question: If convicted of a traffic violation in your personal car:
questions.answerB: Your CDL will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Law enforcement will tell your employer.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violations while driving any vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the conviction. This rule excludes parking violations.

questions.question: When alley docking, you should first:
questions.answerA: Position your vehicle directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerB: Back up directly in front of the alley.
questions.answerC: Stop parallel to the outer boundary of the alley.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS):
questions.answerA: Reduce a vehicle's normal braking capacity.
questions.answerB: Are in addition to other braking systems and do not reduce a vehicle's braking power.
questions.answerC: Are not effective on larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: If equipped, ABS is in addition to a vehicle's normal braking system and does not increase or decrease the braking power of any other system. ABS only activates when a vehicle's wheels are about to lock.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.explanation: Factors that can affect stopping distance include the vehicle's speed, its weight, and the traction provided by the road surface.

questions.question: Scan the road ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Good drivers scan the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. Looking ahead will allow you to identify and react to hazards before meeting them. Be sure to specifically look for vehicles that are coming onto the highway, entering into your lane, or turning.

questions.question: Which of the following is true?
questions.answerA: It is safe to drive on a tire that is missing one or two lug nuts.
questions.answerB: A cracked lock ring on a rim is safe if you are not driving faster than 55 mph.
questions.answerC: A missing clamp on a rim is dangerous and should be corrected.
questions.explanation: Missing clamps, spacers, studs, or lugs are dangerous, as are mismatched, bent, or cracked lock rings. Be sure your tires and rims are in good condition before operating your commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: What helps prevent wheel lockup when braking?
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent wheel lockup while brakes are being applied.

questions.question: When driving in hot weather:
questions.answerA: The air pressure in tires will decrease.
questions.answerB: The engine oil can help to keep the engine cool.
questions.explanation: Because air pressure increases as air expands in the heat, it is important to monitor your tire pressure when driving in very hot weather. To prevent the engine from overheating, there must be an adequate amount of oil in the engine, as well as enough water and antifreeze in the cooling system. Antifreeze is helpful for the engine in both hot and cold weather.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of retarder?
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow the vehicle and reduce the need for braking. The four basic types of retarders are exhaust, engine, hydraulic, and electric.

questions.question: When experiencing cold weather, be sure to check your vehicle's alcohol evaporator:
questions.explanation: An alcohol evaporator can help prevent ice from building up in an air brake system. In cold weather, the evaporator should be checked and refilled every day.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection:
questions.answerA: Should be done in the same way every time.
questions.answerB: Should be done differently every time.
questions.answerC: Does not always need to include all items of concern.
questions.explanation: A pre-trip vehicle inspection should be done in the same way every time. Consistency will help a driver learn all of the proper steps and decrease the possibility of the driver forgetting to inspect something.

questions.question: When taking the basic vehicle control skills test, failing to exit your vehicle properly during any exercise will result in:
questions.answerB: An extra point against your final score.
questions.answerC: Automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: Texting while driving should:
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is a dangerous distraction and is prohibited at all times when operating a CMV.

questions.question: Shortly after a tire has been changed, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop to make sure the lug nuts are still tight.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, you should stop a short while later to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: When operating a vehicle with a dual air brake system, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up before driving to ensure that the fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Let the air compressor build up a minimum of 100 psi pressure in the primary and secondary systems before driving.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the vehicle starts.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up a minimum of 100 psi pressure in both the primary and secondary systems. Watch the air pressure gauges to monitor the pressure levels.

questions.question: The leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle with air brakes should be no more than ____ in one minute during a static leakage test.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a triple combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 5 psi in one minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, it is important to maintain ____ with your vehicle at all times.
questions.explanation: As you exit your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: If you must leave the roadway and drive on the shoulder in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerB: Get both sets of wheels onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Stay on the shoulder until your vehicle has stopped, if possible.
questions.explanation: If you must drive onto the shoulder to avoid a hazard, stay on it until you come to a stop; then signal, check your mirrors, and merge back into traffic. Avoid braking on the shoulder at speeds higher than about 20 mph. To help maintain control, always keep one set of wheels on the pavement, if possible.

questions.question: An encroachment is when:
questions.answerA: A driver does not appear for their scheduled basic skills test.
questions.answerB: A vehicle touches an exercise boundary line during the basic skills test.
questions.answerC: A driver fails one section of the basic skills test.
questions.explanation: An encroachment during the basic vehicle control skills test is when an exercise boundary line is touched or crossed by any portion of the applicant's vehicle. Every encroachment will be counted as an error.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, a look is when:
questions.answerA: A driver checks the gauges on their instrument panel.
questions.answerB: A driver checks their blind spots.
questions.answerC: A driver walks to the back of their vehicle to check its position.
questions.explanation: A driver uses a look when they open their door, leave their seated position, and walk to the back of the vehicle to check its position. During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.
