questions.question: Doors should be closed while a school bus is being driven, except when:
questions.answerB: Needing to cool off the inside of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: There is no vehicle next to the bus.
questions.explanation: The doors of a school bus must be kept closed any time the bus is moving, except when it is crossing railroad tracks.

questions.question: After students unload at the school, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Not be concerned with the students' whereabouts.
questions.answerB: Leave after the students have entered the school building.
questions.answerC: Walk through the bus to check for any sleeping students.
questions.explanation: After students unload at school, a school bus driver should walk through the bus to check for sleeping students, hiding students, and items that students may have left behind. Students should exit the bus in an orderly fashion with the driver supervising.

questions.question: If there is a fire on a school bus, the students:
questions.answerB: Should stay on the bus but be moved to a part of the bus unaffected by the fire.
questions.explanation: If a school bus is on fire, or if there is a threat of fire, it is mandatory for a bus driver to evacuate the students from the bus.

questions.question: If a tornado is approaching and there is no nearby shelter, where should students go?
questions.explanation: If students are evacuated due to a school bus being in the direct path of a sighted tornado, the driver should lead them to shelter in a nearby building. If no such shelter is available, the driver should escort them to a nearby ditch or culvert. They should avoid areas that may be subject to flash flooding and should be far enough away from the bus that it would not fall on them if it tipped over.

questions.question: When driving a school bus, mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.explanation: You should always check the adjustment of all your mirrors before operating a school bus.

questions.question: When taking the basic vehicle control skills test, failing to exit your vehicle properly during any exercise will result in:
questions.answerB: An extra point against your final score.
questions.answerC: Automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Show where the power steering fluid dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Check for adequate power steering fluid.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the power steering fluid level is above the full mark.
questions.explanation: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to indicate where the power steering fluid dipstick or reservoir sight glass is located. You will need to show that the power steering fluid is within a safe operating range.

questions.question: During the basic control skills test, you will receive points if you:
questions.explanation: The examiner will score the number of times your vehicle touches or crosses an exercise boundary line. Each encroachment will count as an error, resulting in points against your skills test score.

questions.question: Loading and unloading a bus:
questions.answerB: Should be supervised by someone other than the driver.
questions.explanation: Passengers may stumble when getting on or off of a school bus. The driver should caution passengers to watch their step when exiting.

questions.question: An inside rearview mirror is used to:
questions.answerB: Inspect the outside of the bus.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus. It should be adjusted to show every student on the bus, including the students directly behind the driver.

questions.question: The overhead rearview mirror is located:
questions.answerA: On the right side of a bus.
questions.answerB: On the steering wheel of a bus.
questions.answerC: Above the windshield inside a bus.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is mounted directly above the windshield on the driver’s side of the bus. This mirror should be used to monitor students inside the bus.

questions.question: When operating a school bus, mirrors should be adjusted:
questions.explanation: It is critical to the safe operation of a school bus that mirrors be properly adjusted. Always check each mirror before operating the bus.

questions.question: The inside rearview mirror is used to:
questions.answerB: See potential hazards on the road.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.explanation: The overhead inside rearview mirror in a school bus is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Hop directly from their seat to the ground.
questions.answerB: Maintain at least one point of contact with their vehicle.
questions.answerC: Be turned to face their vehicle.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.

questions.question: When approaching a school bus stop, the bus driver should:
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should always approach bus stops slowly and cautiously.

questions.question: If taking the driving test and the route does not include a railroad crossing, you:
questions.answerA: Will not have to do anything related to a crossing.
questions.answerB: May have to explain how you would cross railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Will have to take the test again on a route that does include a railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: If your on-road driving test route does not include a railroad crossing, you may be asked to explain and demonstrate the proper railroad crossing procedures to the examiner at a simulated location.

questions.question: Loading and unloading a bus:
questions.answerB: Does not need to be supervised.
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year during loading or unloading of school buses than while riding on school buses. Therefore, it is critical that school bus drivers follow appropriate safety procedures during loading and unloading.

questions.question: When students board a bus, they should:
questions.answerA: Sit in the back row first.
questions.answerB: Sit in the back row only after all other seats are filled.
questions.answerC: Be seated as far from the driver as possible.
questions.explanation: Students should not occupy the back row of a school bus unless the bus is full. The closer to the front of a bus that students are seated, the safer they will be in the event of a rear-end collision. Students with special needs should sit near the driver.

questions.question: School buses:
questions.answerB: Are only equipped with ABS if students who are younger than 10 years of age will be on the bus.
questions.explanation: In general, school buses manufactured after 1998 or 1999 must be equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS). Many older buses are equipped with ABS as well.

questions.question: If a driver needs to exit a school bus to ensure all waiting students have boarded, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Turn the bus off and take the key.
questions.answerC: Ask a student to keep an eye on the steering wheel.
questions.explanation: While students are boarding a school bus, if the driver cannot account for a student outside, they should secure the bus, take the key with them, and check around and underneath the bus for the missing student.

questions.question: If your bus has a manual transmission, what should you never do when crossing railroad tracks?
questions.explanation: Do not shift gears while crossing railroad tracks. Your vehicle could stall and get stuck in the crossing.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, a look is when:
questions.answerA: A driver checks the gauges on their instrument panel.
questions.answerB: A driver checks their blind spots.
questions.answerC: A driver walks to the back of their vehicle to check its position.
questions.explanation: A driver uses a look when they open their door, leave their seated position, and walk to the back of the vehicle to check its position. During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: If a tornado is approaching and there is no nearby shelter, where should students go?
questions.explanation: If students are evacuated due to a school bus being in the direct path of a sighted tornado, the driver should lead them to shelter in a nearby building. If no such shelter is available, the driver should escort them to a nearby ditch or culvert. They should avoid areas that may be subject to flash flooding and should be far enough away from the bus that it would not fall on them if it tipped over.

questions.question: Loading and unloading a bus:
questions.answerB: Does not need to be supervised.
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year during loading or unloading of school buses than while riding on school buses. Therefore, it is critical that school bus drivers follow appropriate safety procedures during loading and unloading.

questions.question: When completing a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull forward directly into the parking space.
questions.answerB: Back up past the parking space, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Hop directly from their seat to the ground.
questions.answerB: Maintain at least one point of contact with their vehicle.
questions.answerC: Be turned to face their vehicle.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.

questions.question: If your bus is equipped with a roof-mounted strobe light, it should be used:
questions.explanation: If equipped, a school bus's roof-mounted strobe light should be used when conditions create an environment of limited visibility.

questions.question: Properly adjusted crossover mirrors allow you to see all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: The right and left front tires touching the ground.
questions.answerB: The area in front of the bus.
questions.answerC: The tops of the right and left rear tires.
questions.explanation: Properly adjusted crossover mirrors on a school bus should allow the driver to see the entire area in front of the bus, from the front bumper at ground level to a point where direct vision is possible. The mirrors should also display the right and left front tires touching the ground, as well as the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection and looking into the fifth wheel gap, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure there is a gap between the kingpin and the locking jaws.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.
questions.answerC: Make sure the locking jaws are loose.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a tractor/trailer coupling, look into the fifth wheel gap and make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be score you on specific driving maneuvers as well as on your general driving behavior. You must drive in a safe and responsible manner; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and not cause an accident or commit a moving violation.

questions.question: When completing an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then drive straight back.
questions.answerB: Drive straight back, then pull forward to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the right. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: If your vehicle's ABS is malfunctioning:
questions.answerA: You will not have any working brakes.
questions.answerC: You should only use the parking brake.
questions.explanation: Anti-lock brakes are meant to keep a vehicle's wheels from locking up during hard applications. If your vehicle's Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunctions, its standard braking functions should still be in place. You should continue to drive and brake in a normal manner.

questions.question: When students are being picked up by a school bus:
questions.answerA: The students should wait at a designated bus stop.
questions.answerB: The driver should pick up students whether or not they are at the designated bus stop.
questions.answerC: The parents should choose where the bus stop will be located.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should load and unload students only at designated stops that have been approved by appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: When students are boarding a school bus, the driver should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Check all mirrors for students rushing toward the bus.
questions.answerB: Count the number of students at the bus stop and ensure all have boarded.
questions.answerC: Allow student to board in pairs.
questions.explanation: When approaching a bus stop, a school bus driver should count the number of students waiting and ensure that they all board the bus. The driver should check their mirrors for any students who may be running to the stop. Students should board slowly in a single-file line.

questions.question: If a school bus needs to be evacuated, passengers should :
questions.answerA: Always exit through the rear door.
questions.answerC: Always exit through the front door.
questions.explanation: When preparing to evacuate a school bus, the driver must quickly determine which of the bus's exits is safest for passengers to use.

questions.question: During the driving test, when encountering a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle on the tracks if the other vehicle is going too slow.
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle to check for a train.
questions.answerC: Not change gears while your vehicle is on the tracks.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, do not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in a railroad crossing.

questions.question: As students exit a school bus, the driver should watch to ensure that they:
questions.answerB: Do not get caught on the handrail or door.
questions.explanation: It is possible for students to be injured, or even killed, as a result of their clothing, accessories, or bodies getting caught on a handrail or door while exiting a school bus. The driver should closely watch students as they exit to ensure that they have all unloaded the bus successfully and have reached a safe location.

questions.question: The overhead rearview mirror is located:
questions.answerA: On the right side of a bus.
questions.answerB: On the steering wheel of a bus.
questions.answerC: Above the windshield inside a bus.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is mounted directly above the windshield on the driver’s side of the bus. This mirror should be used to monitor students inside the bus.

questions.question: If "Inhalation Hazard" appears on a shipping paper, the shipper should provide which placard?
questions.answerB: Poison Gas or Poison Inhalation Hazard
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on the shipping paper or package, you must display the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" or "Poison Gas" placards, as appropriate.

questions.question: When Division 1.3 materials are being transported, the floor liner should be:
questions.explanation: You should use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors must be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are any metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: Shippers package in order to ____ hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Shippers package hazardous materials in a way that is meant to completely contain the materials. Vehicles should be placarded to communicate the risk of the cargo.

questions.question: Many products classed as poison are also:
questions.explanation: Many hazardous materials classified as poisonous are also flammable.

questions.question: Unless the package is clearly unsafe, a driver needs ____ to accept a package.
questions.explanation: When a shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package has been prepared according to Hazardous Materials Regulations (HMR). Unless a package is clearly unsafe or noncomplying with HMR, you may accept the shipper’s certification concerning the proper packaging of a material.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, the best way to learn about transporting hazardous materials is to:
questions.explanation: While the manual includes all of the information required to pass the hazardous materials knowledge test, you should consider reading the manual as only the first step to learning about the topic. You can learn more by reading and understanding the federal and state rules about the transportation of hazardous materials, as well as by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials may need to be:
questions.answerB: Circled by a pen or marker.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be distinguished in one of three ways. They must be entered first on the shipping paper, highlighted in a contrasting color, or properly marked with an "X" in a column titled "HM."

questions.question: To transport hazardous materials, what does a driver need?
questions.answerB: A CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement
questions.answerC: A CDL with a tank endorsement
questions.answerD: A CDL with a cargo endorsement
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to drive a vehicle of any size that is used for transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: If transporting hazardous materials, a shipper should warn others by:
questions.answerA: Posting HazMat placards on their truck.
questions.answerB: Putting flashing lights on their truck.
questions.explanation: Shippers of certain kinds of hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs, known as placards, on any transporting vehicles. Shippers are required to provide applicable placards, labels, shipping papers, and emergency response information.

questions.question: If a package of hazardous materials is not large enough to hold a label, it should be labeled:
questions.answerC: By being placed in a certain part of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If a hazardous materials label will not fit onto a package, it may be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: If your engine runs a pump used during delivery of compressed gas, you should turn off the engine:
questions.explanation: Unless your engine runs a pump for product transfer, turn it off when loading or unloading a compressed gas tank. If you do use your engine to run a pump, you should turn the engine off after the product transfer but before unhooking the hoses.

questions.question: A clue that your shipment contains hazardous materials is that:
questions.answerA: The shipper is in the business of firework or munition dealing.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that involves such materials. Examples include paint dealers; chemical suppliers; scientific supply houses; pest control businesses; agricultural supply firms; and dealers in explosives, munitions, or fireworks.

questions.question: Placards showing the type of hazardous materials in a vehicle are usually which shape?
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: ____ is responsible for properly labeling hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials properly. It is a good idea for the driver to ensure the materials are properly labeled.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle:
questions.answerB: May only be moved in an emergency.
questions.answerC: May be driven if the cargo is not radioactive.
questions.explanation: A vehicle that lacks the proper placards for any hazardous materials on board may not be driven, except as necessary to protect life and property in an emergency.

questions.question: A manifest for transporting hazardous waste:
questions.answerC: Must be attached to the outside of the trailer.
questions.explanation: If you are transporting hazardous waste, you must carry with you a Uniform Hazardous Waste Manifest. The manifest must be signed by hand.

questions.question: To transport hazardous materials, a driver needs:
questions.answerB: A CDL with hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a tank endorsement.
questions.explanation: To drive a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, you must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.

questions.question: A hazardous material's identification number should appear:
questions.answerC: On a sticker near the material's shipping container.
questions.explanation: A material's ID number must appear on its accompanying shipping paper as well as on its packaging. It also must appear on cargo tanks and other bulk packaging.

questions.question: A material’s hazard class reflects:
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material.
questions.answerB: How quickly the material must reach its destination.
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will be placed into one of nine classes to explain the type of risks associated with the material.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerA: The shipping paper matches the markings and labels on packages.
questions.answerB: The shipping paper is written in code.
questions.answerC: All packages are labeled as poison.
questions.explanation: It is always a good idea to compare package markings and labels to accompanying shipping papers. Always make sure the shipper has displayed the correct basic description on the shipping paper and has provided the proper labels on the packages.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials. They must supply the warning placards.

questions.question: Shipping papers should be:
questions.answerC: Easily seen by anyone entering the cab.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: If a package of explosives has an oily stain or shows dampness, the driver should:
questions.answerC: Use towels to absorb the liquid.
questions.explanation: You should never transport damaged packages of explosives. Do not accept a package that seems damp or has an oily stain.

questions.question: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a background check through which agency?
questions.explanation: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a federal security threat assessment done by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 materials should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gases), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids), the use of heaters in the same space is generally prohibited.

questions.question: A shipping paper:
questions.answerA: Is not needed for most shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Is required for all shipments of hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can be kept in a digital file.
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to provide proper shipping papers to communicate the risks of the materials.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you may park no closer than ____ from the nearest building.
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you should not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building, unless you are parking for a short period of time while performing an operational necessity, like refueling.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials must be listed first.
questions.answerB: The hazardous materials must be written larger.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials must be listed in red ink.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper lists both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be entered first.

questions.question: Load hazardous materials:
questions.explanation: Always load hazardous materials away from heat sources. Be aware of regulations on explosive or flammable materials that prohibit them from being loaded in cargo spaces with heaters.

questions.question: In general, before loading or unloading any flammable liquids, an engine should be:
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump. Ground the tank before opening the filling hole and maintain the ground until after closing the filling hole.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, the best way to learn about transporting hazardous materials is to:
questions.explanation: While the manual includes all of the information required to pass the hazardous materials knowledge test, you should consider reading the manual as only the first step to learning about the topic. You can learn more by reading and understanding the federal and state rules about the transportation of hazardous materials, as well as by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials properly. It is a good idea for the driver to ensure the materials are properly labeled.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle may be:
questions.answerB: Either awake or asleep inside the vehicle.
questions.explanation: A person attending a parked placarded vehicle must be either awake inside the vehicle or they must be within 100 feet of it. If not inside the vehicle itself, the person must have a clear view of the vehicle. The person attending may not be inside the sleeper berth.

questions.question: How often do hazardous materials employees need to be trained?
questions.answerB: At least once every three years
questions.explanation: Employees who work with hazardous materials must be trained and tested at least once every three years.

questions.question: If you're transporting explosives and your vehicle breaks down, you should notify other drivers:
questions.answerC: By standing on the roadway and waving your arms.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down while you are transporting explosives and you need to use warning signals, use reflective triangles or red electric lights. Never use burning signals, such as flares or fuses, when transporting explosives.

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the box must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Packages that contain liquid containers must have orientation markers. Arrows displayed on the box should be pointing in the correct upright direction.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation surrounds the package and will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The package should be transported in the cab.
questions.answerC: The package should be loaded on their side.
questions.explanation: Radiation will surround each package of radioactive materials and pass through to all nearby packages. The number of packages that can be loaded together is controlled.

questions.question: How do you label a package if the hazardous materials label will not fit onto the package?
questions.answerA: Place the label on a tag securely attached to the item.
questions.answerB: Attach a QR Code to be scanned.
questions.answerC: Reduce the size of the HazMat label to fit it completely on the item.
questions.explanation: Shippers should place applicable diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on hazardous materials packages. If a label will not fit entirely onto a package, shippers may instead place the label on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: Before loading or unloading flammable liquids, the engine should be:
questions.explanation: Unless you must run the engine to operate a pump, you should always turn off the engine before loading or unloading flammable liquids.

questions.question: Placards showing the type of hazardous materials in a vehicle are usually shaped like what?
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are diamond-shaped.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 materials should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gases), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids), the use of heaters in the same space is generally prohibited.

questions.question: A placard indicating hazardous materials is which shape?
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials may need to be:
questions.answerB: Circled by a pen or marker.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be distinguished in one of three ways. They must be entered first on the shipping paper, highlighted in a contrasting color, or properly marked with an "X" in a column titled "HM."

questions.question: On a shipping paper describing both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials may be identified by being:
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper includes information about both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous items must be clearly identified on the paper. They may be entered first, highlighted in a contrasting color, or identified with an "X" placed before the shipping description.

questions.question: Who must mark and label the materials for shipping?
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to warn drivers and others about the risks of the materials by putting hazard warning labels on packages, putting placards on the transporting vehicles, and providing proper shipping papers and emergency response information.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are usually shaped like:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are usually diamond-shaped.

questions.question: Many products classed as poison are also:
questions.explanation: Many hazardous materials classified as poisonous are also flammable.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle:
questions.answerB: May only be moved in an emergency.
questions.answerC: May be driven if the cargo is not radioactive.
questions.explanation: A vehicle that lacks the proper placards for any hazardous materials on board may not be driven, except as necessary to protect life and property in an emergency.

questions.question: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must carry a fire extinguisher with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: A placard indicating hazardous materials is shaped like a:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are diamond-shaped.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you must park at least ____ from any building.
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, do not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building; a place where people gather; or an open fire.

questions.question: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a background check through which agency?
questions.explanation: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a federal security threat assessment done by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: What does a shipping paper describe?
questions.answerB: How the materials will be transported
questions.answerC: Who should accept the materials being transported
questions.explanation: Among other information, shipping papers must include a description of the specific hazardous materials being transported.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you may park no closer than ____ from the nearest building.
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you should not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building, unless you are parking for a short period of time while performing an operational necessity, like refueling.

questions.question: If your engine runs a pump used during delivery of compressed gas, you should turn off the engine:
questions.explanation: Unless your engine runs a pump for product transfer, turn it off when loading or unloading a compressed gas tank. If you do use your engine to run a pump, you should turn the engine off after the product transfer but before unhooking the hoses.

questions.question: If a driver stops and leaves their vehicle while transporting hazardous materials, the shipping papers should be:
questions.answerB: Left in the front seat of the cab.
questions.answerC: Placed in a box under the passenger seat.
questions.explanation: If a driver stops and exits their vehicle, the hazardous materials shipping papers must be left on the driver's seat.

questions.question: If you notice a cargo leak, you should identify the leaking hazardous materials by:
questions.explanation: If you discover a cargo leak while transporting hazardous materials, use the shipping papers, label, or package location to identify which materials are involved. Do not try to touch or smell the leaking materials to determine what they are because doing so could result in injury or death.

questions.question: Unless excepted, a shipping paper must list:
questions.answerC: The location of fire departments along the planned route.
questions.explanation: Unless excepted, hazardous materials shipping papers must list an emergency response telephone number.

questions.question: If transporting hazardous materials, a shipper should warn others by:
questions.answerA: Posting HazMat placards on their truck.
questions.answerB: Putting flashing lights on their truck.
questions.explanation: Shippers of certain kinds of hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs, known as placards, on any transporting vehicles. Shippers are required to provide applicable placards, labels, shipping papers, and emergency response information.

questions.question: When transporting hazardous materials, placards:
questions.answerB: Should be used on all four sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should be used only by Class A licensed drivers.
questions.explanation: When required, hazardous materials placards must be placed on all four sides of a vehicle transporting hazardous materials.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose. Check the tightness of the nuts if you see any rust in the area.

questions.question: In poor weather, many drivers:
questions.answerA: Like to drive in front of trucks.
questions.answerB: Like to drive to the sides of trucks.
questions.explanation: In bad weather, many automobile drivers will follow large trucks too closely, particularly if visibility is poor.

questions.question: Traction is important in:
questions.explanation: You will not be able to brake or steer your vehicle without adequate traction. Ensure that your tires are in proper working condition before beginning a trip.

questions.question: When you are pulling a trailer, the air supply control lever should be in its ____ position.
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "normal" position, it is properly set for you to pull a trailer.

questions.question: When should you slow for a curve?
questions.explanation: You should always slow to a safe speed before entering a curve. Slowing while within the curve could cause a skid.

questions.question: Mirrors should be used:
questions.answerA: Only when there may be an emergency.
questions.answerC: By a helper to monitor your blind spots.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should frequently check the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle.

questions.question: The more alcohol in the body:
questions.answerA: The quicker the liver will digest the alcohol.
questions.answerB: The less effect the alcohol will have on the individual.
questions.answerC: The longer it will take to remove the alcohol from the body.
questions.explanation: The body removes alcohol at a fixed rate. The more alcohol consumed, the longer it will take for the body to remove the alcohol from its system.

questions.question: Before a trip, you should make a visual check of a coupling to ensure that:
questions.answerA: There is no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel.
questions.answerB: There is no mud on the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: When performing a visual check of coupling devices, you should make sure there is no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel. Ensure that the locking jaws are securely closed around the kingpin.

questions.question: When parking, you should not use the parking brake if:
questions.answerC: There is snow on the ground.
questions.explanation: If your brakes are hot after coming down a steep grade, you should not use your parking brake when parking. Let your brakes cool before applying the parking brake or risk damaging the brakes.

questions.question: What do air brakes use to make the brakes work?
questions.explanation: Many large CMVs are equipped with air brakes. An air braking system uses compressed air to operate.

questions.question: When using a fire extinguisher on a fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Get as close to the fire as possible.
questions.answerB: Stand as far away from the fire as possible.
questions.answerC: Aim the extinguisher at the top of the fire.
questions.explanation: When using a fire extinguisher, you should stand as far away from the fire as possible. Aim the extinguisher at the base of the fire, not at the flames. If you are not sure which kind of extinguisher should be used on a fire, particularly a hazardous materials fire, you should wait for the firefighters to arrive and allow them to extinguish it.

questions.question: The air compressor is connected to the:
questions.explanation: The air compressor of an air brake system is connected to the engine through gears or a v-belt. The compressor may be air-cooled or cooled by the engine cooling system.

questions.question: What kind of brakes do most newer heavy-duty trucks use?
questions.explanation: Most newer heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems which use a single set of brake controls.

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection should include:
questions.answerA: A check of the engine oil level.
questions.explanation: When examining the engine compartment during a pre-trip inspection, you should check the engine oil level, the radiator coolant level, and the condition of the hoses.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle unattended:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should be used.
questions.answerB: The parking brake only needs to be used if the vehicle is parked on a slope.
questions.answerC: The parking brake should not be used, as it can damage the tires.
questions.explanation: In general, you should always use the parking brake when parking your vehicle. However, you should not apply the parking brake if your brakes are very hot or if your brakes are wet and temperatures are below freezing.

questions.question: When mirrors are properly adjusted:
questions.answerA: No part of the vehicle should be visible in the mirrors.
questions.answerB: A part of the vehicle should be visible in the mirrors.
questions.answerC: More than half of each mirror should show the vehicle.
questions.explanation: A properly adjusted mirror will show some portion of the vehicle. This will provide a point of reference to help the driver judge the distance of other objects to the vehicle.

questions.question: To avoid a hazard, you:
questions.answerA: Should always come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: May need to swerve your vehicle out of the way.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the best way to avoid a hazard. If there is not enough space for you to stop to avoid coming into contact with the hazard, swerving out of the way may be your safest option.

questions.question: To prevent a vehicle from rolling backward when beginning to move forward from a stopped position, you should:
questions.explanation: To prevent a vehicle with manual transmission from rolling backward when you begin to move forward from a stopped position, you can partly engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.

questions.question: Air brakes use ____ to function.
questions.explanation: Air brakes function through the use of compressed air.

questions.question: To make it easier to leave a parked position, you should park:
questions.answerA: In a way that allows you to back up when exiting.
questions.answerB: In a way that allows you to pull forward when exiting.
questions.answerC: Only on the side of roadways, not in parking lots.
questions.explanation: Backing is always dangerous and should be avoided whenever possible. When parking, look to park in a space that will allow you to pull forward when exiting.

questions.question: A distracted driver:
questions.answerA: Usually follows the rules of the road.
questions.answerC: Is a good person to follow.
questions.explanation: Distracted drivers perceive hazards on the road more slowly than drivers who are focused, or they do not perceive hazards at all.

questions.question: Parked delivery trucks may be hazardous because:
questions.answerB: People are often in a hurry when exiting such trucks and may not look for other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Packages often fall out of the trucks and into the road.
questions.explanation: Passing parked delivery or postal trucks can be dangerous because the driver may be in a hurry and pull into traffic without warning, or may they suddenly step out of the vehicle without checking for other traffic.

questions.question: If trying to correct a drive-wheel braking skid, the driver should:
questions.explanation: To correct a drive-wheel braking skid, you should first remove pressure from the brake pedal to allow the locked wheels to begin rolling again. Quickly steer in the direction you want to go, then countersteer to prevent your vehicle from skidding in the opposite direction.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts can indicate that the nuts are loose. If you find rust near the wheel nuts, check their tightness before beginning to drive.

questions.question: When driving at night, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Make sure your glasses are clean.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you can see as well as possible, don't wear sunglasses when driving at night. If you wear eyeglasses, make sure they are clean and unscratched. Make sure you are rested and alert before driving at night.

questions.question: How do ice cream trucks become hazardous to other drivers?
questions.answerA: Ice cream trucks must be kept cold.
questions.answerB: Children often run toward an ice cream truck without looking for other traffic.
questions.answerC: Ice cream trucks leave trails of water and ice on the roadway.
questions.explanation: Ice cream trucks can create hazardous conditions for other drivers because they attract children. Children often do not notice or pay attention to other vehicles on the roadway when running to or from ice cream trucks.

questions.question: A truck tractor built after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: When using your turn signal, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn the signal off before beginning the turn.
questions.answerC: Signal only if vehicles are in front of you.
questions.explanation: Always begin signaling well in advance of a turn. This is the best way to ensure that other drivers do not try to pass you. Without using a turn signal, drivers may assume that you are merely slowing down or stopping when you are planning to turn.

questions.question: To prevent a trailer from rolling over while turning, you should:
questions.explanation: Rollovers happen when an operator turns too fast. Drivers should be sure to slow down before entering turns and curves, especially when pulling a trailer.

questions.question: Hydroplaning happens most often when:
questions.answerA: A vehicle is traveling faster than 60 mph.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is most likely to occur when driving on wet roads with tire pressure that is too low and tire tread that is too worn. If there is enough water on the road, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: When driving a vehicle, rough acceleration is:
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: If there is ice on the front of your side mirror:
questions.answerB: You can expect ice to be on the roadway.
questions.answerC: There will not be ice on the roadway.
questions.explanation: If your mirrors or wiper blades become icy while you are driving, you can expect the road surface to be icy as well.

questions.question: When parking, you should not use the parking brake if:
questions.answerC: There is snow on the ground.
questions.explanation: If your brakes are hot after coming down a steep grade, you should not use your parking brake when parking. Let your brakes cool before applying the parking brake or risk damaging the brakes.

questions.question: On a curve, the posted speed limit:
questions.answerA: Is safe to be driven in any vehicle.
questions.answerB: Can still permit a vehicle to tip over.
questions.answerC: Is understood to be the minimum legal speed limit.
questions.explanation: The posted speed limit on a curve may be safe to be taken by cars, but can still be too fast to be taken by larger vehicles, such as trucks. An operator driving their truck at the posted limit on a curve could cause their vehicle to tip over.

questions.question: Hydroplaning:
questions.answerB: Usually happens when vehicles are traveling faster than 65 mph.
questions.answerC: Can occur with a minimal amount of water on the roadway.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be a large amount of water on the road for this to occur.

questions.question: ABS allows you to:
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to help prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. With ABS equipped on your vehicle, you should drive and brake in the same manner that you would without it.

questions.question: If a tire fails, you should:
questions.explanation: Braking after a tire fails can result in a loss of control. Stay off your brakes, if possible, until your vehicle has slowed considerably.

questions.question: A lane change:
questions.answerC: Should be done with a jerking motion.
questions.explanation: Lane changes should be made slowly and smoothly.

questions.question: Black ice is:
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. The surface will look like a wet road. Always be alert to black ice if the road looks wet when the temperature is below freezing.

questions.question: Routine vehicle inspections should be done to ensure:
questions.explanation: The most important reason to inspect your vehicle is to ensure the safety of yourself and other road users.

questions.question: Emergency equipment, such as fire extinguishers, are:
questions.answerA: Only needed in vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Required in all commercial motor vehicles.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles must carry appropriate emergency equipment, including fire extinguishers.

questions.question: When backing a trailer, you must turn the steering wheel:
questions.answerA: In the direction you want the trailer to move.
questions.answerB: In the direction opposite of where you want the trailer to move.
questions.answerC: To the left until backing is complete.
questions.explanation: When backing a vehicle with a trailer, you must turn the steering wheel in the direction opposite of where you want to go. Once your trailer starts to turn, you should turn the steering wheel the other way to follow the trailer.

questions.question: A broken exhaust system:
questions.answerA: Can allow poisonous fumes to enter the cabin.
questions.explanation: A broken exhaust system can let poisonous fumes into a vehicle's cab or sleeper berth. Be sure to inspect your exhaust system for any loose, broken, or missing parts.

questions.question: An improperly placarded vehicle:
questions.answerB: May only be moved in an emergency.
questions.answerC: May be driven if the cargo is not radioactive.
questions.explanation: A vehicle that lacks the proper placards for any hazardous materials on board may not be driven, except as necessary to protect life and property in an emergency.

questions.question: In a double or triple combination, the ____ trailer should be directly behind the cab.
questions.explanation: When positioning trailers in a combination, the most heavily-loaded trailer should be the closest to the tractor. The lightest trailer should be positioned in the rear.

questions.question: When conducting a check of the engine compartment during a vehicle inspection, you should not:
questions.explanation: When inspecting the engine compartment, you should check the oil level, coolant level, and windshield washer fluid level, among other things.

questions.question: More than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths are caused by:
questions.explanation: More than half of all accident-related truck driver deaths are a result of truck rollovers. To help prevent a rollover, be sure to load cargo low to the ground and centered on your rig. Take corners slowly and carefully.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.explanation: Always speed up smoothly and gradually so that your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: In cool weather, as the temperature begins to rise and ice begins to melt:
questions.answerA: It is usually safe to drive.
questions.answerB: The road will become even more slippery.
questions.explanation: As the temperature begins to rise and ice on the road begins to melt, the road surface will often become even more slippery. Water from the slight melting will sit on top of the ice, decreasing the available traction even more. Always decrease your speed and drive with caution when traveling on slippery surfaces.

questions.question: What is the Johnson bar?
questions.answerA: A hand valve that works the trailer brakes
questions.answerB: A valve that indicates the fuel level
questions.answerC: A valve that limits the amount of cargo
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes. Using it while a vehicle is in motion could cause a skid.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, a CDL applicant may be asked to:
questions.explanation: When checking the engine compartment during the vehicle inspection test, you will need to check the engine oil level.

questions.question: Shaded areas of a road:
questions.answerB: Are usually blocked from all moisture, so they cannot freeze.
questions.answerC: Will remain slick after ice has melted on other areas of the road.
questions.explanation: Because they are exposed to less sunlight and warm up more slowly, shaded areas will remain icy and slippery after ice on other areas of the road has melted.

questions.question: On any upgrade, gravity will:
questions.explanation: A vehicle will be slowed down by gravity on any uphill grade. You may need to switch to a lower gear to climb a steep grade.

questions.question: How many daily hours of sleep does an adult need to maintain alertness?
questions.explanation: Being properly rested is essential to the safe operation of a CMV. To maintain alertness, most people need eight to nine hours of sleep per night.

questions.question: Lower the risk of jackknifing by:
questions.explanation: You can prevent skidding by steering, accelerating, and braking smoothly. If your drive wheels or trailer wheels begin to skid while you are driving a tank vehicle, the vehicle could jackknife.

questions.question: You should not use your mirrors:
questions.answerC: To determine how fast you are traveling.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be a part of your driving routine, it is particularly important to check your mirrors when changing lanes, turning, merging, and making tight maneuvers.

questions.question: If feeling tired while driving, it is best to:
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel tired while driving, the only safe action to take is to stop and get some sleep. Trying to fight the fatigue and press on is very dangerous and can result in a fatal crash. You should not rely on artificial stimulants; these may help keep you awake a while longer, but they won't make you more alert.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver is involved in a crash on the road ahead, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and tell them of the driver's behavior.
questions.answerC: Block the driver in with your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you see a crash involving an aggressive driver, you should stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and inform them of the aggressive behavior you witnessed.

questions.question: Rearward amplification refers to:
questions.answerA: The amount of noise projected to the rear of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: The number of trailers that can be pulled by a tractor.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with trailers are vulnerable to rollover due to the "crack-the-whip" effect, which is caused by rearward amplification.

questions.question: Before operating a tank, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Check vapor recovery kits, if applicable.
questions.answerC: Remove a third of their fuel.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tank vehicle before operation, make sure all specialty equipment is in safe working condition. This includes vapor recovery kits, grounding and bonding cables, and emergency shut-off systems.

questions.question: When starting a vehicle, warning lights and buzzers:
questions.answerA: Should not light up or sound.
questions.answerB: Should turn on and shut off quickly.
questions.answerC: Should turn on and remain on.
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the warning lights and buzzers should turn on, then quickly turn off.

questions.question: Scan the road ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Good drivers scan the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. Looking ahead will allow you to identify and react to hazards before meeting them. Be sure to specifically look for vehicles that are coming onto the highway, entering into your lane, or turning.

questions.question: When drivers turn, they usually:
questions.answerA: Look in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Look in the direction opposite the turn.
questions.explanation: When turning, drivers usually look in the direction of their turn. If a driver fails to signal before a turn or lane change, their body movements may still provide a clue that they are planning to turn.

questions.question: After a vehicle is started, warning lights and buzzers:
questions.answerA: Should stay on for several minutes.
questions.answerB: Should turn off within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Should stay on until manually turned off.
questions.explanation: After a vehicle is started, the warning lights and buzzers should go out after a few seconds. If the warning signals do not turn off, there may be something wrong with the vehicle.

questions.question: On a slippery road, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Make turns as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: Under slippery conditions, you should drive slowly and smoothly. Make turns as gently as possible and do not pass other vehicles unless you have to.

questions.question: If unable to tell if the road is becoming icy and slippery, a driver:
questions.answerB: May open their window and feel the front of the side mirror for ice.
questions.answerC: Should look at the road closely.
questions.explanation: If you think the road surface may be becoming icy but you are not certain, you can open your window and feel the front of the side mirror, mirror support, or antenna. If ice has formed on any of these items, the road is likely becoming icy as well.

questions.question: When pulled off on the side of the road:
questions.answerA: A driver should keep the driver’s side door open.
questions.answerB: A driver should turn on the emergency flashers.
questions.answerC: The driver should wave their arms.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, make sure to use your four-way emergency flashers. This is particularly important at night.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep your vehicle in front of them.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, don't let yourself be provoked by their actions or angry gestures. Do not risk provoking the other driver by making eye contact. Get out of their way if you can do so safely.

questions.question: On a shipping paper, the identification number, shipping name, and hazard class should:
questions.answerA: Be abbreviated if using a small piece of paper.
questions.answerB: Only be abbreviated if the abbreviations are easy to understand.
questions.explanation: On hazardous materials shipping papers, the identification number, shipping name, and hazard class must not be abbreviated, unless specifically authorized in the hazardous materials regulations.

questions.question: If you are turning left at an intersection where there are two available turn lanes:
questions.answerA: It is best to use the right lane.
questions.answerB: It doesn’t matter which lane you use.
questions.answerC: It is best to use the left lane.
questions.explanation: You may have to swing right to safely make a left turn. If there are two left turn lanes available at an intersection, you should always begin your turn in the rightmost lane.

questions.question: When refueling a vehicle carrying hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The engine should be left on.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The gas nozzle may be left unattended.
questions.explanation: If you need to refuel a vehicle carrying hazardous materials, you must first turn off the engine. While refueling, someone must be at the nozzle and controlling the fuel flow at all times.

questions.question: When entering a curve, you should:
questions.explanation: You should always slow down to a safe speed and shift into a lower gear before entering a curve.

questions.question: Older trailers are not equipped with spring brakes. This means that if the air supply for a vehicle's air braking system leaks away:
questions.answerB: The trailer will not have brakes.
questions.explanation: Older trailers do not have spring brakes. This means that if the air supply in an older trailer's air tank has leaked away, there will be no working brakes connected to the trailer and its wheels will turn freely.

questions.question: A broken exhaust system:
questions.answerA: Can allow poisonous fumes to enter the cabin.
questions.explanation: A broken exhaust system can let poisonous fumes into a vehicle's cab or sleeper berth. Be sure to inspect your exhaust system for any loose, broken, or missing parts.

questions.question: Alcohol begins to affect the body:
questions.answerB: After several drinks have been consumed.
questions.explanation: Alcohol consumption impairs muscle coordination, reaction time, depth perception, vision, judgement, and inhibition. For some people, signs of impairment may begin with the first drink of alcohol. It is safest to not operate any motor vehicle after consuming alcohol in any amount.

questions.question: Unless excepted, a shipping paper must list:
questions.answerC: The location of fire departments along the planned route.
questions.explanation: Unless excepted, hazardous materials shipping papers must list an emergency response telephone number.

questions.question: If the brakes pull to one side or the other when used:
questions.answerC: They will be the most effective.
questions.explanation: If the brakes pull to one side or the other when used, it is an indication of brake trouble.

questions.question: What is the tractor protection valve?
questions.answerA: A valve that keeps air in the brake system should a bad leak occur
questions.answerB: A valve that prevents the trailer from being accidentally released
questions.answerC: A valve that prevents the vehicle from going too fast
questions.explanation: A tractor protection valve keeps air in a tractor or truck air brake system should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak. The valve will close automatically if the pressure drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: When loading liquid cargo, it is important to remember:
questions.answerA: That there may be construction work along your planned route.
questions.answerB: That too much cargo can slow down your vehicle.
questions.answerC: That the liquid will expand in transit.
questions.explanation: Factors that affect how much liquid is safe to load into your tank include how much the liquid will expand in transit, the weight of the liquid, and legal weight limits. All liquids expand at different rates, so be sure you know the rate at which your cargo will expand once you begin to drive.

questions.question: When turning, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn off your turn signal just before starting the turn.
questions.answerC: Signal only if vehicles are in front of you.
questions.explanation: Be sure to activate the appropriate turn signal well in advance of a turn or lane change. Signal continuously throughout the turn and make sure to cancel the signal after the turn is completed, if your vehicle doesn't have self-canceling signals.

questions.question: The standee line:
questions.answerA: Is a line that passengers should not cross.
questions.answerB: Is a line upon which passengers should stand.
questions.answerC: Is a line that should be used as passengers exit the bus.
questions.explanation: On a bus designed to carry standing passengers, no passengers may stand in front of the rear of the driver's seat. Any such bus must have a line on the floor, or some other marking, that indicates where passengers may not stand. This is called a standee line.

questions.question: A Class 1 hazardous material is:
questions.explanation: The first hazardous materials class includes explosives such as ammunition, dynamite, and fireworks.

questions.question: Which gas would cause concern due to a faulty exhaust system?
questions.explanation: A leaking exhaust system can introduce carbon monoxide, which is poisonous, into the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: When driving in hot weather:
questions.answerA: The air pressure in tires will decrease.
questions.answerB: The engine oil can help to keep the engine cool.
questions.explanation: Because air pressure increases as air expands in the heat, it is important to monitor your tire pressure when driving in very hot weather. To prevent the engine from overheating, there must be an adequate amount of oil in the engine, as well as enough water and antifreeze in the cooling system. Antifreeze is helpful for the engine in both hot and cold weather.

questions.question: One way to prevent drowsiness while driving is to:
questions.answerC: Get adequate sleep the night before the trip.
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued can be extremely dangerous. Strategies for preventing drowsiness while driving include getting a full night's sleep before a trip; having someone ride with you; scheduling trips for times during which you are normally awake; and avoiding medications that may cause drowsiness. Exercising regularly can increase your energy levels and make you less likely to become tired while driving.

questions.question: When turning, you should:
questions.answerB: Turn off your turn signal just before starting the turn.
questions.answerC: Signal only if vehicles are in front of you.
questions.explanation: Be sure to activate the appropriate turn signal well in advance of a turn or lane change. Signal continuously throughout the turn and make sure to cancel the signal after the turn is completed, if your vehicle doesn't have self-canceling signals.

questions.question: An empty truck:
questions.answerA: Requires a shorter stopping distance than a full truck.
questions.answerB: Requires a longer stopping distance than a full truck.
questions.answerC: Takes the same distance to stop as a full truck.
questions.explanation: Empty trucks require longer stopping distances than full trucks because they have less traction available.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerA: Can be avoided by eating while driving.
questions.answerB: Can be increased by pre-programming radio stations.
questions.answerC: Can be avoided by not engaging in complex conversations with others.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: Exhaust system parts should be:
questions.answerB: Rubbing against other parts of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When inspecting an exhaust system, you should verify that parts of the system are not loose, broken, or missing. The system's parts must be properly mounted and should not be rubbing against moving parts of the vehicle.

questions.question: If you are unsure if there is enough space for your vehicle to safely pass under an upcoming bridge, you should:
questions.explanation: If you aren't sure that you have room for your vehicle to safely fit under an overhead object, you should slow down while approaching it. Seek an alternate route, if possible.

questions.question: Maintaining a cushion of space between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead is:
questions.answerA: Not encouraged, as it slows the flow of traffic.
questions.answerB: Encouraged, as it allows you time to react to unexpected hazards.
questions.answerC: Only encouraged if you are traveling with a passenger.
questions.explanation: For safe driving, it is essential that you maintain cushions of space on all sides of your vehicle. This helps to ensure that you will have time to take appropriate action if a problem arises.

questions.question: Black ice is:
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. The surface will look like a wet road. Always be alert to black ice if the road looks wet when the temperature is below freezing.

questions.question: If a vehicle is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), when the vehicle is started:
questions.answerB: The ABS indicator light should turn on, then quickly shut off.
questions.answerC: The steering wheel will not move until the air tanks are full.
questions.explanation: After starting the engine of a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), the indicator light should come on and then turn off. If the light stays on, something is wrong with the ABS.

questions.question: How can you check hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brake pedal three times then apply firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should not move.
questions.answerB: Pump the brake pedal three times then apply firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should move slowly toward the floor.
questions.answerC: Pump the brake pedal three times then apply firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly rise.
questions.explanation: Check hydraulic brakes by pumping the brake pedal three times before applying firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak or some other problem in the braking system.

questions.question: When asked to make a turn while taking your driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signal, but only if other cars are present.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only in the direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: A broken exhaust system can:
questions.answerA: Let poisonous fumes into the cab.
questions.explanation: Defects in an exhaust system are very dangerous because they can cause poisonous fumes to enter the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: To make it easier to leave a parked position, you should park:
questions.answerA: In a way that allows you to back up when exiting.
questions.answerB: In a way that allows you to pull forward when exiting.
questions.answerC: Only on the side of roadways, not in parking lots.
questions.explanation: Backing is always dangerous and should be avoided whenever possible. When parking, look to park in a space that will allow you to pull forward when exiting.

questions.question: Which of the following is an indication of standing water on the roadway?
questions.answerB: Portions of the pavement that are dry
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning can occur in places where water collects on the road. Clear reflections, tire splashes, or rain drops on the road can indicate the presence of standing water.

questions.question: If making a tight turn, the operator of a CMV should:
questions.answerA: Be able to drive as fast as the driver of a car.
questions.answerB: Not be concerned about speed, but focus on the road.
questions.answerC: Warn drivers behind by braking early and slowing gradually.
questions.explanation: Drivers behind you may not anticipate how slowly your CMV must travel to safely make a right turn. You can help warn them in advance by braking early and slowing gradually.

questions.question: ____ are the most likely to be affected by strong winds.
questions.explanation: Strong winds can make it difficult for a driver to maintain control of their vehicle. Usually, this is especially true for drivers of lighter CMVs.

questions.question: If other vehicles are having a difficult time getting around your truck on a road with two or more lanes, you should:
questions.explanation: You should stay in the right lane of a multilane road if your vehicle is being slowed down by a heavy load. Allow other vehicles to pass your truck using the left lane.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerC: The cargo is mostly in the front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: It is essential to the safe operation of a CMV that cargo be properly loaded. Improper loading can affect handling and damage the vehicle. Additionally, improperly loaded materials can cause injury or death by falling off of the vehicle.

questions.question: If driving on a surface with poor traction, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is always good to accelerate slowly.
questions.answerB: To keep from losing control of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: So that they do not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: To avoid a loss of control, you should accelerate slowly when driving in poor-traction conditions, such as rain or snow.

questions.question: During a trip, gauges are:
questions.answerB: The only way a driver can learn of potential trouble with the vehicle.
questions.answerC: A way to learn of potential trouble with the vehicle.
questions.explanation: During a trip, you should regularly check the gauge and instrument panels, mirrors, tires, cargo, and lights for signs of trouble.

questions.question: Most bus accidents happen:
questions.explanation: Bus accidents most commonly occur at intersections. Use caution, even if the intersection is controlled by signs or signals.

questions.question: To check the automatic transmission fluid level in some vehicles, you will have to:
questions.explanation: In some vehicles, it may be necessary to leave the engine running when checking the automatic transmission fluid level.

questions.question: A cardboard box on the roadway:
questions.answerA: Should be expected to be on the roadway.
questions.answerC: Could contain a heavy object that could damage vehicles.
questions.explanation: Almost any foreign object on the road poses some potential danger. For example, even something as seemingly harmless as a cardboard box could contain a hard or heavy object that could damage your vehicle.

questions.question: Generally, a bus should be refueled:
questions.answerA: In a closed building with passengers on board.
questions.answerB: With passengers on board in an open space.
questions.explanation: You should avoid refueling a bus while passengers are on board, unless absolutely unavoidable. In particular, you should never refuel a bus with passengers on board while inside a closed building.

questions.question: Eating while driving is:
questions.answerA: A good way to save time.
questions.answerC: Acceptable if you are eating foods that are easy to eat.
questions.explanation: Smoking, eating, or drinking are distracting activities and should be avoided while you are driving. Instead, plan ahead and allow yourself time to stop to eat when making a lengthy trip.

questions.question: When approaching a construction worker who is near the road, you should:
questions.explanation: Always drive with caution through work zones. You should make a particular point of reducing your speed when workers are on or near the roadway.

questions.question: If backing a truck:
questions.answerA: You should rely on your mirrors to guide you.
questions.answerB: You should first walk the area to become more familiar with obstacles.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in reverse, you should first walk around your vehicle to look at the path of travel and check for obstacles. Because mirrors have blind spots, you cannot rely exclusively on them. It is recommended to use a helper whenever possible.

questions.question: If driving so slowly that you could impede other drivers, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using your four-way flashers.
questions.explanation: If you must drive so slowly that you will impede the flow of traffic, you should turn on your four-way flashers to alert drivers behind you (as long as local laws allow the use of flashers).
